column1: The testicles develop in the infant's abdomen as the baby grows in the womb.
Undescended testicle repair surgery is recommended for patients whose testicles do not descend on their own.
The surgeon makes a cut in the groin.
A small cut is made in the scrotum, and a pouch is created.
This surgery is recommended for infants older than 1 year whose testicles have not descended into the scrotum (cryptorchidism).
Risks for any anesthesia are: - Reactions to medications - Problems breathing Risks for any surgery are: - Bleeding - Infection
A small percentage of men will have fertility problems.
Men with undescended testes have higher rates of testicular cancer than those with normal testicle development, even if they have a fully descended testicle on the other side.
